chapterMeaning: The Yoga of the Three Divisions of Faith
sanskrit:
आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियः।
यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं शृणु॥
transliteration:
āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ |
yajñas tapas tathā dānaṁ teṣāṁ bhedam imaṁ śṛṇu ||
translation: The food which is dear to each person is also of three kinds, as are sacrifice, austerity, and charity. Hear now the distinction between them.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna introduces a detailed analysis of how the three gunas (sattva, rajas, and tamas) manifest in everyday life, beginning with food preferences. This verse serves as a transitional statement, announcing that just as faith is threefold according to one's nature, so too are the fundamental aspects of spiritual and material life—food, sacrifice, austerity, and charity—divided into three categories based on the predominant guna.

The significance of starting with food (āhāra) is profound in yogic philosophy. Food is not merely physical sustenance but directly influences one's mental state, consciousness, and spiritual progress. The Gita recognizes that what we consume shapes our thoughts, emotions, and ultimately our spiritual evolution. By understanding our food preferences, we can discern our predominant nature and consciously work toward sattvic choices. This verse establishes the framework for the following verses which will elaborate on each category, providing practical guidance for spiritual aspirants to align their daily activities with their higher spiritual goals.
speaker: Krishna
